attributes.action: Impose stricter requirements on reallocation of road space by local authorities
attributes.background: The Government should require councils undertake full consultations and equality assessments that engage with the emergency services, the disabled, businesses & residents impacted by traffic displacement before reallocating road space or implementing Low traffic Neighbourhoods.
attributes.additional_details:
The Traffic Management Act places a duty on councils to ensure traffic moves freely and quickly on their roads and those of nearby authorities. We believe some road schemes displace and slow traffic, causing significant congestion, increased idling & reduced air quality. Congestion can also delay emergency vehicles potentially causing risk to life. These impacts can disproportionately affect the disabled, the BAME community, small businesses & low paid workers who rely on vehicles.

Increasing requirements for consultation and assessing the impact of proposed road schemes, with financial penalties for failing to do so, would ensure such schemes do not go ahead unless they would be beneficial. Existing schemes should be required to meet these new requirements or be removed.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Reduce the residential speed limit to 20mph in England
attributes.background: The Welsh parliament, Senedd Cymru, have recently backed plans to reduce the speed limit in residential areas to 20mph in Wales and we ask that residential speed limits across England are reduced to 20mph too to save lives and improve the quality of life for people in residential areas.
attributes.additional_details:
89% of pedestrian and 83% of cyclist casualties happen on urban roads. Slower speeds mean fewer collisions and a lower risk of fatal injury. Research has shown that a 1mph reduction in average speed can reduce collision frequency by 6%.
 
If a pedestrian is hit by a vehicle at 20mph, they are far more likely to survive than if they had been hit by a vehicle travelling at 30mph.
 
Lower speeds mean fewer particulates and greenhouse gases emitted, therefore fewer negative air quality impacts.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Do not cut domestic Air Passenger Duty
attributes.background: The Government has announced it wants to cut air passenger duty on domestic travel. This cut will ensure that the most polluting of all travel methods actually contributes more to the UK's carbon footprint. We are in a climate emergency. The cut should not be implemented.
attributes.additional_details:
The government's own study (reported at www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-49349566) shows domestic air travel as the worst contributor to climate change, per mile, of all modes of transport.

This year the UK hosts COP26, to focus all countries on the carbon reductions needed to avoid the worst effects of climate change.

We should show leadership & commitment to cutting our emissions, and not enact a policy which will increase pollution, reduce air quality, and expand our carbon footprint.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Introduce a ban on sales of new petrol and diesel cars by 2025 in the UK
attributes.background: Both Norway and the Netherlands have voted to ban the sales of new petrol and diesel cars by 2025 and 2030 respectively. It will be impossible to hit global carbon reduction targets without radical actions, such as this. The UK should be leading the way on reducing the impact of Climate Change.
attributes.additional_details: The UK has committed to being Carbon Neutral by 2050, to achieve this we will need to rapidly reduce CO2 emissions with 33% coming from transport. Bringing in the ban of new petrol and diesel vehicles will accelerate the transition to low carbon transport which itself will improve air quality.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Revoke Development Consent for the Riverside Energy Park in SE London
attributes.background: The Government should revoke the Development Consent Order for the Riverside Energy Park incinerator in South East London, to protect air quality, local wildlife, and the appearance of the area. The incinerator would be located near large populated urban areas.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Set stricter legal targets for air quality and increase funding for research
attributes.background: The Government’s planned new legal targets for air quality must align with the WHO air quality guideline levels. It should also increase funding for research and development to develop cleaner energy sources and reduce plastic air pollution from tyres. This will also help combat climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Each year at least 28,000 people in the UK die prematurely because of air pollution, including children. Air pollution has been linked to heart disease, lung disease and cancer, and can exacerbate allergies, skin conditions and pregnancy complications. 
 
Currently we are above the World Health Organisation guideline levels for multiple pollutants. Data from the World Bank shows that 66% of the UK population were exposed to pollution above the WHO standards in 2017.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Reduce the national speed limit to 60 MPH on motorways and dual carriageways
attributes.background: Road transport is a major contributor to CO2 emissions and poor air quality; these are critical issues which contribute massively to climate change. The longer we leave reducing these emissions the more painful remedial measures will have to be, both in cost and impact on daily life.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government should immediately reduce the national speed limit to 60 MPH on motorways and dual carriageways for all vehicles. This modest reduction could make a worthwhile cut in CO2 emissions with the added benefit of reducing collisions and the stress of driving at relatively low cost. 
We don’t need to wait for any recommendations to come from the Glasgow COP26. We can do our bit now to avoid a climate emergency. Remind the Government that our planet needs urgent help now!

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Trees planted in the grounds of every new home and to be maintained by law
attributes.background: Each new home is to have a young UK species tree, planted within its grounds and be legally protected for the duration of the properties life span. This would create an industry of tree growers, reduce co2 emissions  and promote UK tree plantation.
attributes.additional_details: We are struggling to reduce carbon emissions and require soical initiatives to help address this growing problem, while creating awareness and better mental health. We need to create low cost natural carbon storage while improving residential areas and improving air quality. This method of CO2 reduction would have secondary benefits of reducing rain water runoff by tree absorption and natural shading reducing solar heat gains.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Introduce a National Reforestation Scheme
attributes.background: Start a permanent reforestation scheme of planting locally appropriate tree species across the UK in all public owned spaces & incentivise planting on private land. Establish a panel of experts to recommend operational measures. Nominate a Gov't department to design and implement the scheme.
attributes.additional_details: Long term local and global  benefit of large scale diverse tree planting include: Improvement in quality of life for all, climate change prevention, creation of habitats for all wildlife, better air quality, prevention of flooding, a healthier population, prevention of loss of habitats and soil erosion and job creation. It is unethical to disregard this as it would be cheap and reasonable to start a scheme that could have a diverse and profound impact for the greater public good.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Abolish (or raise threshold on) luxury car tax for Ultra Low Emission Vehicles
attributes.background: Cars valued at or exceeding £40,000 are subject to the Luxury Car Tax (£1600 over 5 years). This should be abolished, or have the threshold raised significantly, for Ultra Low Emission Vehicles (ULEVs) as it impedes numerous Government initiatives and targets for transport and emissions.
attributes.additional_details: The tax contradicts the Government policies on reducing emissions, improving air quality, and rolling out ULEVs. Many comparative ULEVs which are suitable as replacements for petrol/diesel cars are higher priced by virtue of the advanced technologies and manufacturing processes required, and therefore are still more costly to produce. It is counter productive to offer grants for purchasing the vehicles and then tax consumers for running these vehicles, which help tackle the climate emergency.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Help protect our environment by permanently banning unnecessary travel to work
attributes.background: The Government should require all workers to work from home unless they are unable to do so. People can be significantly healthier and happier working from home, and banning all unnecessary travel to work should benefit both the environment and our mental health.
attributes.additional_details:
The coronavirus outbreak, and associated restrictions on movement, has resulted in large numbers of people working from home. This has allowed many to save money, catch up on sleep, and spend more time with their families.
 
Reduced activity, particularly commuting, resulting from coronavirus has had substantial environmental benefits. Air quality has improved dramatically in many areas, and much wildlife has been able to flourish.
 
This is the best time to make permanent changes and move forward.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban wood and garden waste burning.
attributes.background: We call on the Government to ban the burning of wood and garden waste in residential areas. We want to enjoy clean air in the summer and wintertime.
attributes.additional_details:
Wood burning is the largest contributor to wintertime pollution (Particulate matter pollution - PM2.5) and an increase in PM2.5 levels can result in increases death rates as the quality of the air is made worse.

We need to change our attitudes towards wood burning. We cannot afford to regard the smell of wood smoke as something evocative, nostalgic, or natural. Science is not subject to debate, burning wood and garden waste is shortening lives.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban garden and allotment fires.
attributes.background: It's not illegal to light bonfires/garden fires, and there are no national restrictions on when or how often they can be burned. The main concern is environmental damage especially as we are in a climate crisis, but it also affects air quality and wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban all advertising of carbon-emitting SUVs in the UK
attributes.background: The extraordinary growth of carbon-emitting SUVs has contributed hugely to global car emissions (almost entirely cancelling out carbon gains made by the growth of Electric Vehicles) and these cars add to poor air quality that studies show kills tens of thousands each year.
attributes.additional_details:
Cigarette ads are rightly banned, and there is no reason why car manufacturers should be allowed to continue to promote carbon-emitting and polluting SUVs.

In 1965, amidst growing concern over the impacts that smoking had on health, advertising cigarettes on TV was banned in the UK. By 2005 all promotion had been banned, and smoking has declined as a result. Yet we still allow car manufacturers to promote carbon-emitting SUVs that impact air quality and contribute to carbon emissions. Why? In line with sensible precedent on banning advertising to drive down smoking, this government should ban all promotions of SUVs.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Ban bonfires between May 1st - October 1st
attributes.background: The Government should ban bonfires between May 1st and October 1st.
attributes.additional_details:
It is a fact that the world's weather is altering. The UK has drier, hotter spring and summers now. Many countries already have this ban in place.

A ban on bonfires between these dates should have many positive effects. The fire service should have fewer call outs to out of control garden burns, thus lessening the strain on public services. Air quality should improve.

Last but not least people would not be subjected to unwanted smoke and unpleasant smells which can have a negative effect on their lives.This should also reduce the number of complaints being dealt with by local councils.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban the sale of petrol powered garden tools to encourage shift to alternatives
attributes.background: With the world in the grips of an environmental crisis there is absolutely no excuse for the continued use of garden tools that pollute the atmosphere with chemicals and noise, damage people's health, and perpetuate our reliance on fossil fuels.
attributes.additional_details:
Petrol machinery produces airborne pollution that can impair breathing & aggravate existing heart & lung conditions.
 
The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has estimated that a lawnmower can produce the same air pollution as 11 cars. A Swedish study has also found that the emissions from a petrol mower used for one hour are equivalent to those released by a car on a 100-mile journey.
 
A ban on the sale of petrol powered garden tools would encourage a shift to battery powered garden tools. This should improve air quality and could help tackle global warming.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Commit to electrification of the whole East West Rail line & ban diesel on route
attributes.background: Place the environment and sustainable transport at the forefront of the East West Rail project and commit to ensuring that the whole of the project is electrified at the outset and that diesel cannot be used to fuel trains along the entire route.
attributes.additional_details:
“Electric trains are better for the environment than diesel trains, and they’re quieter for both those on board ... and those living close to the railway" (Network Rail who are undertaking significant work to electrify rails to meet the government's target of taking all diesel only trains off the track by 2040)

Failure to commit to this now risks severe disruption to the local habitats and communities not once but twice before the end of the next decade as well as decreasing air quality.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Incentivise companies to get more people working from home
attributes.background: Provide incentives to companies in the form of reduced tax, employers contributions or corporation tax when the company reaches a goal, for example of 25% or 50% of employees working from home on a regular basis.
attributes.additional_details: During the Covid-19 outbreak, many companies have allowed employees to work from home. This has massively reduced congestion and improved air quality.  The plans to meet CO2 targets could be helped enormously by this incentive with the reduction in use of fossil fuels powering private and public transport.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Ban bonfires during daylight hours
attributes.background: Ban any bonfire from occurring before dusk. Bonfires create excessive smoke which has an impact on the quality of air for the community. Everyone is entitled to fresh air and should be able to enjoy their garden.
attributes.additional_details: Bonfires can cause breathing difficulties and are particularly dangerous for anyone suffering with health conditions such as asthma, and can be a risk to the health of children and the elderly. It is also a strain on our emergency services when fires get out of control, and a strain on the environment when clothes need rewashing.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Increase road tax when more than two vehicles are registered to the same address
attributes.background: To ease Parking on our roads we need to take action to reduce Vehicles and the Parking they cause. Fire Services have had issues getting down roads, there is NO need for Everyone to have a Vehicle, it adds Pollution and Climate Charge, we need to free up our Roads getting Gridlocked.
attributes.additional_details:
To tackle Asthma Issues from poor air quality. Congestion it getting worse as above, makes people Lazy. It’s much too Cheap to stick a Vehicle on the Road. We have one car for Two and it works perfectly,
 
Unclog our Roads.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban petrol and diesel vehicles to keep our as air clean as it is now
attributes.background: End the production and use of petroleum powered vehicles on all UK roads. Only allow electric vehicles to be used on the roads by all private drivers & with severe restrictions on commercial use until enough electric commercial vehicles can be produced.
attributes.additional_details: Since the lockdown, air quality around the world has been the best it’s been in a century. Effects of climate change may be reversing across the planet. We the people refuse for it to go back to the catastrophic path we were going down prior to this global event. We want to breathe clean air, as is our birthright. We do not accept the poisoning of our bodies and the destruction of our planet to make a few people rich. End the use of fossil fuel powered vehicles on our roads immediately.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Stop the London ULEZ expansion while the cost of living crisis is ongoing.
attributes.background: The Mayor or London is conduction consultation to expand the ULEZ in Greater London.  Any expansion should be delayed by the Government/Parliament until after the cost of living crisis is resolved.  I fully appreciate the need for air quality and climate control to be addressed but not now or 2023!
attributes.additional_details: Members of the public are already being out stretched to afford the basics to live (food, fuel and home) and any expansion to the London ULEZ will mean an additional charge to use their cars if they do not comply to the emissions standards or the additional cost of replacing a car to one that does.  The poorest members of the public will be made to give up the use of theirs cars which some need for essentials like caring for family members.  This is totally at the wrong time.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the issue you raise is not the responsibility of the Government or Parliament. It is the responsibility of the Mayor of London and the London Assembly.

The London Assembly has its own petitions process. You can find out more about how to petition the London Assembly here:

https://www.london.gov.uk/about-us/london-assembly/petitions

attributes.action: Ban Sport Utility Vehicles (SUVs) from our towns and cities
attributes.background: Restrict the use of SUVs in towns and cities, especially in the main centres and residential areas. Enforce a maximum length and width for vehicles parking on narrow streets and in tight car parks. Allow necessary exemptions for commercial vehicles and those specially adapted for access.
attributes.additional_details:
This recent report from the New Weather Institute https://bit.ly/3uLtTqP shows that the places where SUVs dominate are also where road space is most scarce. Large SUVs are too big for a standard UK parking space, and are some of the most polluting vehicles in terms of air quality and carbon emissions.

SUVs are unsafe. They encourage aggressive driving, and their drivers have less visibility of other road users - particularly children, who may be less tall than the front of the vehicle.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This would be a decision for individual local authorities.

attributes.action: Impose safety restrictions on Chelsea Bridge
attributes.background:
1. Introduce speed cameras on Chelsea bridge 
2. Red line on both sides of bridge to restrict parking at all times
3. Impose fines for motorbikes and cars revving and parking on the Chelsea bridge and on the pavement.
4. Cameras to detect and fine illegal uturns on Chelsea bridge
attributes.additional_details:
Every single weekend there are hundreds of cars and motorbikes parking, speeding, revving engines, doing illegal uturns, driving on the pavement, on Chelsea Bridge.

There is a huge amount of noise and air pollution caused from the cars and even some cars blowing fire from their cars. There is massive disruption to quality of life and sleep to neighbouring residents, and this behaviour places danger to other drivers, and pedestrians from the speed racers and illegal u turns on the bridge.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a matter for Transport for London.

attributes.action: UK to ban the sale and use of all fossil fuels in all settings from 1st Jan 2040
attributes.background: To improve air quality and fulfil the UK's commitment to net zero carbon emissions  by 2050.
attributes.additional_details: To help phase out the use of fossil fuel technologies in all applications throughout the UK.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Remove the newly installed unnecessary bus lanes in Charlton and Woolwich
attributes.background: The recent installation of the at all time bus lanes on the A206 (SE London) have increased congestion levels significantly. As a result there are vehicles queuing all day on this long stretch of the road causing unnecessary congestion, pollution as well as affecting the mental health of the public.
attributes.additional_details:
We believe this is a miscalculated move made by Greenwich Council as the situation has in no way improved air quality but has created dangerous levels of pollution.

We hope this petition will help bring to focus the situation we face in the area and for it to be reassessed and reversed so that Greenwich Council are using the TfL Cycleway 4 funding correctly by installing cycle lanes and not bus lanes.

A petition made on Change.org with over 2000 supports. Our local MP is not willing to help.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a matter for TfL and the local authorities.

attributes.action: Help us remove the HGV’s through Chipping Norton causing dangerous pollution.
attributes.background:
Debate the failure to deliver improvements in line with the AQMA (Air Quality Management) requirements change the route of HGV’S, in Chipping Norton and encourage more electric vehicles(provide more charging posts for EVs). 
Ask for a full debate to create an alternative route for HGV’s.
attributes.additional_details: This issue has remained for more than 10 years and no council had made the decision to improve the level of pollution in Chipping Norton which are now at dangerous levels.

rejection.details:
Decisions about local road restrictions and air quality measures are a matter for the relevant local authority, not the Government or House of Commons.

You can petition West Oxfordshire District Council here: https://cmis.westoxon.gov.uk/cmis/ePetitions.aspx

attributes.action: Ban garden and allotment fires during the Coronavirus pandemic.
attributes.background: We want the government to bring in an emergency measure to ban the burning of wood and rubbish during the lockdown associated with the Coronavirus pandemic.
attributes.additional_details: People are stuck at home and need fresh air more than ever.  Despite the drastic reduction in traffic, air quality from ultra fine smoke particles (PM2.5) is getting worse.  We need to be able to go outside and to ventilate our homes without breathing polluted air.  Poor air quality is already being linked to increased probability of death where people contract COVID-19.  We need to be able to keep as healthy as possible at this critical time.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310468

attributes.action: Do not use 27-acre site in Ashford for lorry park or border control post
attributes.background:
The Government should not use the 27-acre site of beautiful Kentish countryside for a post-Brexit customs centre or lorry park.
 
HGV vehicles are highly polluting, and increasing HGV traffic to this area could have a substantial effect on local air pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Not only is the Brexit lorry park bad for local biodiversity and air quality, but it also threatens disruption to traffic to and from the local William Harvey Hospital and has angered many local residents feeling disregarded.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Stop Farnborough Civic Quarter development plans to cut 237 trees!
attributes.background:
We the constituents of Rushmoor District object to the unnecessary destruction of 237 mature trees which would take place if RBC's current plan for the development of Farnborough Civic Quarter goes ahead. 
This action conflicts with RBC's own Local Plan and adversely impacts the community:
attributes.additional_details:
The trees provide shade combating the urban heat-island effect.

They absorb C02 and felling them means the loss of carbon sinks combating climate change. 

Decrease in air quality close to the airport.

People living in the town centre will be affected by noise pollution.

A lack of green spaces has a negative effect on people's mental health. 

It will cause a huge loss of biodiversity and habitat for wildlife.

We are challenging this development on the grounds of RBC's own Local Plan.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about local developments are a matter for the relevant local authority, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

Rushmoor Borough Council also has its own petitions scheme, which you can find out about here: https://www.rushmoor.gov.uk/media/h5ioha4n/12_-_new_petitions_scheme.pdf

attributes.action: Stop councils from making roads with illegally high pollution even worse
attributes.background: Amend the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984 to require any traffic authority making a traffic order to monitor air quality before and during a scheme, on any roads likely to be impacted by changes, and to suspend the scheme if levels above established safe standards (eg 40 ug/m3 NO2 annual mean).
attributes.additional_details: Local councils and TFL currently have the ability to divert or displace traffic for up to 18 months without consultation, potentially benefiting residents of one road to the detriment of others. Residents of roads suffering from displaced traffic cannot claim compensation. It is vital to protect these residents - more likely to be in poverty or BAME, and less likely to own a car - from the harmful effects of such schemes. The precautionary principle should apply to traffic orders.

rejection.details:
Local authorities already have legal responsibilities to tackle emissions where these exceed national objectives. This includes using traffic and parking management. You can read more about Local Government air quality responsibilities here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-8804/

We have published the following related petitions, which you might like to sign:

Remove guidance and funding for temporary traffic measures that cause congestion: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552306

Impose stricter requirements on reallocation of road space by local authorities: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550887

attributes.action: Stop the increase of cost & operational duration of the daily Congestion Charge.
attributes.background: We object to the Mayor of London’s 30% increase in cost of the daily Congestion Charge. We want determined action to improve air quality, protect people's health and tackle climate change as we emerge from the corona virus crisis, but this should be a collective responsibility, not a personal cost.
attributes.additional_details:
Forcing the general public back on to London’s already packed transport network, where social distancing is near impossible is not appropriate at this crucial time.

We invite government to review the changes to London’s Congestion Charge at this critical time.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the issue you raise is not the responsibility of the Government or Parliament. This is the responsibility of the London Assembly. 
You can petition the London Assembly directly: https://www.london.gov.uk/about-us/london-assembly/petitions

The Government has agreed a package consisting of a mixture of grants and loans based upon a series of conditions agreed by the mayor, including the reinstatement of the congestion charge: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-grants-transport-for-london-funding-package

You could start a petition calling on the Government to reimburse people, or particular groups of people, for the cost of the congestion charge, if that is what you want to happen. You could also start a petition calling on the Government to seek to revise the terms of its support for Transport for London, so that this is not conditional on the reinstatement of the congestion charge.

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you find out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.
 
Find out more: https://committees.parliament.uk/work/192/the-governments-response-to-coronavirus/

attributes.action: Keep Stoke-on-Trent's Victoria and Eutria Roads Open!
attributes.background: We request that the Government (DEFRA) gives Stoke-on-Trent City Council a further extension of time to look at alternatives to the proposed closures of Victoria Road A50 and Eutria Road A53, during peak hours, to help bring the city's air quality in line with DEFRA’s Air Quality Directive.
attributes.additional_details:
The closure of these key roads in the City of Stoke-on-Trent will only act to move pollution into residential areas, as traffic takes alternative routes to their destination. It will also have a detrimental effect on residents and businesses that rely on access to their properties on these roads.

The proposed closures are also a temporary measure to meet targets quickly, where as the alternatives proposed, given more time, will offer a permanent solution to reducing air pollution in this city.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise.  Decisions on how to improve air quality in line with the Government's direction are a matter for the council.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:

https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors 

We could publish a petition calling for the Government to extend the deadline, if that's what you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: Close 'non-essential' stores on Sunday, to improve our quality of life.
attributes.background: For many of us in society, we only have two guaranteed days off a year, Christmas Day and Easter Sunday. I want legislation to ensure that all 'non-essential' workers are given Sundays off. This will not extend to small independent companies and those that offer leisure activities.
attributes.additional_details: Since the UK government went into lockdown it has become apparent that many aspects of our lives are improving. The air quality has improved and we have been able to rebuild connections with our families. The closure of 'Non-essential' companies, for one day a week will result in 52 days a year where we directly tackle our CO2 emissions and improve our standard of living. As the 5th largest economy in the world, surely this means we can afford to improve the lives of its hard working citizens.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310336

attributes.action: Save the Upper Nene Valley countryside from massive industrialisation.
attributes.background:
Stop the large number of distribution centres currently being planned on good agricultural land within the Upper Nene Valley.

Ensure speculative developers are not allowed to exploit budget constrained councils into permitting inappropriate and unsustainable development for short term profit.
attributes.additional_details:
Villages and towns in this beautiful rural area are becoming inundated with large ugly warehouses and more are being planned.

The increase in heavy goods vehicles and subsequent air, noise and light pollution will result in a reduction in the quality of life for all residents in the Upper Nene Valley.

Increased industrialization will contribute to global warming, flooding and climate change.

This loss of countryside will reduce the diversity of plants, animals and birds, never to be regained.

rejection.details:
Local planning decisions within the Upper Nene Valley are a matter for the individual local authority, not the Government or Parliament. As a result it is not possible for the Government or Parliament to take the action you have requested.

If you are concerned about planning decisions in your area you could raise this issue with a local councillor, who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them: https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Plant 30 Million Trees over the United Kingdom
attributes.background: It should be debated and decided that 30 million trees should be planted over the UK with maybe a consideration of air filters regardless of good air quality.
attributes.additional_details: It should be debated and decided that 30 million trees should be planted over the UK with maybe a consideration of air filters regardless of good air quality. if it costs a lot of money we should consider donations maybe 1 pound a tree. the population of the UK is over 60 million so that would almost be 50p per person in the UK population

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552296

attributes.action: Tax fossil fuels proportionately to the damage caused to the environment.
attributes.background: Introduce a tax that would encourage the reduction in use of fossil fuels in order to encourage alternative sources of power and reduce use of ffs. An example of profligate use, growing trend to weekend breaks in European cities. This would also help to reduce road congestion & help reduce other tax
attributes.additional_details:
This is a key issue in the fight to stabilise the climate. Without a disincentive to use fossil fuels any help given to alternative energy and energy saving measures will reduce the demand for fossil fuels and as a consequence reduce the price of ff thus increasing and not reducing consumption.
Funds raised form the tax are badly needed at this time espesially if the govenment intends to support alternatives.
Better air quality, reduce pressure on the NHS
Britian must take the lead at the COP26.

rejection.details:
We think this petition is similar:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/321854

attributes.action: Make permanent positive environmental benefits arising from Covid 19 measures.
attributes.background:
The Government has taken radical action in response to Coronavirus. This has led to short term reductions in emissions and improvements in air quality.

When it becomes possible to lift the 'lockdown', the Government should consider as its greatest priority how to make these benefits permanent.
attributes.additional_details:
It would truly be a tragedy if, after so many people working so hard to tackle Covid 19, the UK did not act as the scientific consensus tells us we must act, to tackle the ongoing Climate Emergency.

We need to reach net zero carbon before the Government's 2050 target. If we act to make permanent reductions which would otherwise be temporary, there is a chance to achieve this much sooner, avoiding or mitigating future climate breakdown, and, indeed, saving lives.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the UK Government or Parliament to take a specific action. We understand that you want the Government to reach its net zero carbon target before 2050, however we're not exactly sure what you mean by "make permanent positive environmental benefits".

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. 

We've published a number of petitions asking for the Government or Parliament to take action on this issue which you may like to sign: 

Support carbon neutral energy alternatives:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300000

Run a Public Awareness Campaign about the Climate and Ecological Emergency:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/301289

Study the impact of home working on the environment and act on the results: 
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/317466

Ban commercial flights on Sundays: 
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/308349

Ban unnecessary travel to work: 
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319793

attributes.action: Post Coronavirus, no trading and no movement of goods on Sundays.
attributes.background: Pass legislation that provides for no trading on Sundays.
attributes.additional_details:
The lockdown during the Covid-19 has clearly demonstrated:
- the desire and benefits arising from more families spending more quality time together. There has been a huge amount of feedback, particularly, children of all ages stating this. 
- The environment, particularly, air quality has improved significantly during the lockdown. Some of that benefit would be retained as there would be significantly less traffic on the roads in a week, then there is presently. 
We have learnt during this crisis, ‘Society’ does exist and such a measure will encourage this.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310336

attributes.action: Regulate and restrict parking for uber motorcycle and scooter delivery drivers
attributes.background:
Regulate and restrict uber motorcycle and scooter delivery drivers from waiting in residential areas and pay and display parking bays without paying for tickets and with no consideration for other road users and residents 
This has a significant impact on air quality and can be unsafe
attributes.additional_details:
I have noticed it is having a big impact on other local businesses and residents as they often park without considering others and cause noise and air pollution often in heavily populated areas 
A local cafe/ restaurant in Enfield that has brought a much needed alternative to the area and created a wonderful space in what was an underused side road is overrun with uber drivers that park outside which impacts on diners.  Additionally the residents above are often disturbed late into the night

rejection.details:
The management of parking spaces in a residential area, and enforcement of any parking restrictions, is a matter for the relevant local authority, not the UK Government or House of Commons. The Government is therefore not directly responsible for the action this petition calls for.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Say no to consett incinerator
attributes.background:
We want the government to stop Durham county council agreeing to the building of an incinerator to burn waste within the Consett area .
Ref. DM/20/03267/WAS
attributes.additional_details: Incinerators harm recycling; our air quality and contribute to climate change. Enmisions include dioxins, Box and ultrafine particulate matter that can be harmful to both human health and the natural environment, there is not enough monitoring, enforcement or transpararency by the industry. Traffic will increase having 22 HGV movements per day carrying waste in and out across the North East adding more pollution. A 50 meter stack will be much higher than any building in the area, therefore the night and industrial nature of this incinerator will cause substantial,adverse and permanent visual effects bringing unacceptable harm and retirement to the character of the landscape.

rejection.details: The decision on this planning application is a matter for Durham County Council, not the UK Government or Parliament.

attributes.action: Ban all garden/allotment fires during COVID-19 lock down
attributes.background: Make it illegal for all garden/allotment fires during COVID-19 lockdown
attributes.additional_details:
People are confined to their house and working from home, they are not getting the amount of quality fresh air they normally would. This has not stopped lighting fires during the lockdown, these fires mean people cannot enjoy their garden or have their windows open whilst they are working.

People are already stressed and feel like prisoners in their own home without this being added onto their stress.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310468

attributes.action: Remove Tfl Ulez compliant cameras in poor communities in South East London
attributes.background: Government approach to address air pollution in communities can not be generalised as communities differ in terms of their needs. I will enjoin Government to do the following in poor communities to address air pollution and improve quality of lives of the inhabitants.
attributes.additional_details:
1. A campaign that will encourage green building 
2. A campaign that will encourage people to ride a bike or walking instead of driving.
3. A campaign that will encourage taking a bus or carpooling. 
4. A campaign that will promote the use of energy efficient light bulbs and appliances. 
5. A campaign that will encourage people to turn 6. Government should focus on renewable fuel 
6.A campaign that will encourage people to buy fewer things that are manufactured using fossil fuels.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about the ULEZ and local advertising for public transport are a matter for Transport for London and the London Assembly, not the UK Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

The London Assembly has its own petitions process. You can find out more about how to petition the London Assembly here: https://www.london.gov.uk/about-us/london-assembly/petitions

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to run national campaigns on some of the things you outline in your list.

attributes.action: Ban Vaping For Toxicity Of Gases To The General Population in UK
attributes.background: Mount a complete study of the toxicity of vaping and e-cigarette gases like Formaldehyde, Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC), CO2, Nicotine, Toxic Metals, and Nicotine in apartment air quality and determine if this should be banned like it is in other countries. Protect citizens from these toxic gases
attributes.additional_details: Living near people vaping in an apartment has been horrific. Then I measured the Formaldehyde, Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) and Carbon Dioxide and the whole air in the apartment became entirely toxic from a few smokers. An air quality meter showed high VOC, Formaldehyde and CO2 ppm gases in indoor air all floors, especially from Open Vaping where juice of unknown origin is burnt using adjustable high voltage pipes. UK children & citizens should not have to grow up in these toxic environments

rejection.details:
We understand you're concerned about the health impact of e-cigarettes, however it's not clear whether you want the sale of e-cigarettes to be completely banned, or simply for the use of e-cigarettes in indoor settings such as apartments to be banned.

You could have a petition calling for a review into the second-hand health impact of e-cigarettes, if that is something you'd like to see happen.

You might also like to sign this petition which calls for related actions:

'Bans the distribution and use of combustable tobacco products in the UK by 2030': https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/593542

attributes.action: Ban the use and sale of all fireworks in the UK including organised displays.
attributes.background: Ban the use and sale of all fireworks and pyrotechnic displays in the United Kingdom as they disturb wildlife, produce waste and harm the environment.
attributes.additional_details:
Around bonfire night, there is a noticeable increase in air pollution and decrease in air quality. This is from particulate matter and dioxins. Approximately 5-10% of all of the UKs dioxin emissions are on this night alone. As gunpowder is the main component, sulphur and metal oxides are emitted as well. 

If the uk is serious about becoming net zero then fireworks must go to meet these targets as well as to remove the litter they cause as well as disruptions and upset to wildlife.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/599738

attributes.action: Prioritise pedestrian and bicycle infrastructure over cars within our cities
attributes.background:
Clear separation of ‘roads’ primarily for inter-city car journeys, and ‘streets’ primarily for pedestrians, bicycles, necessary service vehicles (e.g. emergency, deliveries) and disabled access vehicles

Widen pavements

Create new cycle lanes

Reduce traffic and car speeds in neighbourhoods
attributes.additional_details:
1. Economic Development - people who walk or cycle make more trips to the high street and spend more money 
2. Reduction of Congestion – congestion costs average UK road user 115 hours and £894 a year  
3. Air Quality – automobile pollutants harm our health and contain greenhouses gases that cause climate change  
Demand – 77% support measures to encourage more walking and cycling 
Realistic – separated cycle lanes work. In London introduction increased usage by 53% 
  
Stats: www.cyclinguk.org

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or Parliament is responsible for.

Decisions about prioritising pedestrian and bicycle infrastructure is a matter for local authorities, not the Government or Parliament.

You could start a petition asking the Government to provide funding for local authorities to prioritise pedestrian and bike infrastructure over cars, if that's something you'd like to happen. You could also ask the Government to require local authorities to meet certain standards for pedestrian and cycling infrastructure.

attributes.action: London Authorities should be banned for massacre any trees in London.
attributes.background: UK air pollution is a public health emergency, London boroughs have to recognise that air pollution in London is a critical issue that must be tackled, duty to governance and policies for improving the natural environment, for innovative air quality projects and reduction of CO2 emission in London.
attributes.additional_details:
Investigations into whether the public authority has failed to comply with environmental law, and employee decision-making.
Local Authorities in London should be initiated into the roles and importance of trees.
A tree has the ability to provide an essential of life for all living things on our planet: oxygen, and the power to remove harmful gases like carbon dioxide making the air we breathe healthier.
The government should take in considerations my proposal of a new Bill  
already written.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a matter for the London Assembly and the London Mayor.

The London Assembly has its own petitions process. You can find out more about how to petition the London Assembly here: https://www.london.gov.uk/about-us/london-assembly/petitions

We could accept a petition calling to changes for the felling of trees across England, if that's something you'd like to happen.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Require developers felling trees to fund reforestation projects: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/578554

attributes.action: Require all new-build supermarkets to be built with a living green roof
attributes.background: Government should introduce legislation requiring all new-build supermarkets to be built with a living green roof.  These help lower the supermarket’s carbon footprint, increase its energy efficiency, reduce surface run-off following rain and improve overall air quality for the community.
attributes.additional_details:
Air pollution is the biggest environmental cause of poor health. Up to 1,200 deaths each year in Greater Manchester are contributed to by poor air quality, which is likely to be increased by Covid-19. 
LIDL are proposing to build a new supermarket at Mocha Parade, Salford.  Two years ago they built a store in Malmesbury in Wiltshire with a living green roof.  Unless the government introduces legislation, LIDL and their competitors will not do the same in Salford or elsewhere.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/332338.

attributes.action: Encourage employers to allow their employees to work from home
attributes.background: During lockdown there has been a massive reduction on air pollution, much of which must be down to more people working from home.
attributes.additional_details: Less air pollution for everyone, better health and less illness. Wildlife returning to areas where they been absent for many years. Less time travelling by car and public transport = a cleaner environment, less time travelling for the employee, less stress, more quality time with family due to wasted travelling time.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/318057

attributes.action: Ban bonfires during daylight hours
attributes.background: Ban any bonfires from occurring before dusk
attributes.additional_details:
Bonfires create excessive smoke which has an impact on the quality of air for the community. Everyone is entitled to fresh air, particularly in their own garden, and especially during the Covid-19 pandemic. Bonfires cause breathing difficulties and this is particularly dangerous for anyone suffering with Covid-19 symptoms, asthma and all babies and children.
It is also a strain on our emergency services when fires get out of control, and a strain on the environment when clothes need rewashing.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/310468
